hedline.hl1: New Quarters for Blue Sky Studios

abstract.p: Blue Sky Studios, which won Oscar for short film Bunny, is moving its headquarters from Harrison, NY, to White Plains; photo (M)

block.p: BLUE SKY STUDIOS, the computer animation company that won an Oscar last year for its short film ''Bunny,'' is moving from its quarters in Harrison to the 17th floor at 44 South Broadway in White Plains.
The move will accommodate the 13-year-old company's growing work force, which has risen to 150 from 70 employees last summer.

BLUE SKY STUDIOS, the computer animation company that won an Oscar last year for its short film ''Bunny,'' is moving from its quarters in Harrison to the 17th floor at 44 South Broadway in White Plains.
The move will accommodate the 13-year-old company's growing work force, which has risen to 150 from 70 employees last summer.
With production having started for ''Ice Age,'' the company's first full-length feature, Blue Sky is expected to have 200 animators and technicians working on the project by the end of the year.
Blue Sky, a unit of 20th Century Fox Animation and Fox Film Entertainment, recently bought several supercomputers from Compaq, considerably increasing the animation company's computing power.
The new 512 Compaq AlphaServer DS10L systems will enable Blue Sky ''to compete successfully in a dramatically changing marketplace,'' Chris Meledandri, president of 20th Century Fox Animation, said.
''Ice Age,'' which will center on the adventures of a woolly mammoth, a sloth and a saber-toothed tiger, is being directed by Chris Wedge, who picked up the Oscar for ''Bunny.''
It will feature the voice talents of Ray Romano, John Leguizamo and Jane Korkowski from the television show ''Ally McBeal.''
